text: 2011 bottle. Aroma is prunes, grapes, burnt caramel, and bourbon. Tastes pretty oxidized. Fairly hot alcohol, big prune, some mild caramel and butterscotch. Decent overall. I bet it was way better a few years back.

22oz bottle, 2011 vintage pours an oily brown with no head. Nose has vanilla, lightly vegetal, caramel, brown sugar, booze, port, fortified wine. Flavor is bitter with soap and pine, sweet with caramel too, whiskey, vanilla, grappa. Finishes oily and still a touch hot.
From a bottle share at a gathering January 9, 2016. It s a clear dark amber With no head. The aroma is boozey and the taste is bourbon and finishes in a sweet molasses.
From a bottle at the Nuplastikk Returns DC gathering January 2016. Pours a murky mahogany. Bourbon aroma. Flavors of fruitcake, bourbon, oak and vanilla. Boozy finish.

Sample at Sour Sunday 2015.

Dark brown with a small head. Aroma and taste of dried fruit, chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, oak and caramel. The mouthfeel was thick and the aftertaste long. A nice beer to sip.

A fantastic barleywine. Had the whiskey barreled version. Pours a super muddy brown with a thick tan head, pours almost like a nitro. Smells of caramel, vanilla, and whiskey. Taste is super creamy, with whiskey in the middle, and vanilla in the finish. Great dessert beer. Had in the bottle.
Bottle. Somewhat murky dark brown, with a thin head. Sweet brown sugar, dark fruit, plum, raisin, prune, caramel, bourbon, vanilla, some alcohol, and graham crackers. Pretty nice.

2009: All the faults of the base beer are nearly gone in this big boozy rendition. Still darker than most, and maybe still a touch thin - but so stinking smooth you dont care. Booze, vanilla and dark fruit mostly. Nice sipper.

Bottle - 2011 vintage. Pours hazy ruby chestnut with a small brown head that dissipates fairly quickly with good lacing behind. Aroma is bourbon, toffee, vanilla, oak, a bit of funk in there as well. Flavor is medium sweet, medium bitter, a faint note of distracting tartness. Full bodied and hot. Good, not great.
This one poured a medium murky brown clor with a beige head. Aroma was of caramel, dark fruits, and bourbon. Flavor was similar, Very well balanced and integrated BA barleywine.

Bottle shared thanks to beerman6686. I didnt take note of the year. Pours a dark reddish brown color with a slight tan head. Aromas of caramel and vanilla and leather. Taste is slightly sweet with some heat from the bourbon. Medium bodied.

Bottle from a trade that was consumed for breakfast post Hunahpu Day in Tampa. Good morning! 2012 bottle. Snifter pour was extreme muddy brown with a thin slightly off-white head. Not much in lacing. Serious aroma of dark fruits and candies alike. Some booze on the nose but not bad. Also graham cracker and Nilla Wafers. The taste was bold. Serious dark fruits like prunes, dark candied sugars, heavy malts, graham cracker, Nilla Wafers, oak barrel, and booze. Full body, very mild carbonation. FInish is somewhat booze but well balanced and smooth. Creamy mouth feel. AWESOME B Wine.

Bottle from 2012: &nbsp Deep burnt brown sugar in color, thin sudsy off-white head, little lacing. &nbsp Huge sweet caramel biscuity aroma, bourbon, vanilla, graham cracker and dark pitted fruit. &nbsp Big sweet brown sugar and bourbon flavors up front, vanilla, graham cracker, caramel, toffee, and marshmallow. &nbsp Very warming, dark pitted fruit seems to come out as this one finishes. &nbsp Not all that bubbley, a little flat, but smooth and sweet. &nbsp Lingering dark pitted fruit, aged caramel, and bourbon. &nbsp This is one complex Barley Wine, and perhaps so far from the norm that its hard to say its actually a Barley Wine any longer. &nbsp Tasty as tits tho!

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2013 On tap at Hamiltons, pours a deep dark mahogany with as small beige head. Aroma of vanilla notes, caramel, and light bourbon. Flavour brings out quite a lot of bourbon barrel notes, vanilla, and caramel. Very complex, boozy and vanilla-like. An elegant, slow-sipper. Excellent stuff.

Bottle (2012): The aroma consists of moderate chocolate, oak, vanilla, bourbon, and toffee. It pours a dark brown with some orange transparency when held to the light. It has a one finger khaki head that fades to a thin film. There is some sporadic webbing left on the sides of the glass. The flavor starts with moderate chocolate, toffee, caramel, and a touch of molasses. The finish has moderate vanilla, light-moderate bourbon, oak, light maple syrup, and just a hint of mint. Its medium-full bodied with mild carbonation and a sticky mouthfeel. Overall, an excellent example of what I like in a barrel aged Barley Wine.

10 ounce sample on tap at Preserve in Winters, CA. 2012 vintage. The aroma has some peaty bourbon and sweet vanilla primarily. Some molasses essence is also present. Pretty quaffable. Opaque ruddy mahogany body with a small, yellowish head present. Starts sweet, sugary, and malty. Almost a bubble gum flavor, followed by a little buttery diacetyl, too. Nice bourbon flavor in the middle. Finishes sweet. Ethanol is hidden well. Pretty tasty.

2012 bottle, purchased at BeerCraft in Rohnert Park and shared last night. Pours dark amber with minimal head. Aroma of caramel, vanilla, bourbon. Tastes sweet with practically no bitterness, but surprisingly not cloying. Right up my alley for what I like most in a barleywine.

22. 2012, opened August 2013. Thanks, G! Pours a clear medium amber with bright golden brown edges. Very scant light tan head that does not stick around for long. Mild sweet nose, showing bourbon and some sweet heavily caramelized malt. Sticky thick full body. Caramel, toffee, molasses, apricot, vanilla...sweet but not cloying. Definitely very little hop presence. Very nice but not a bruiser and not overly developed in any one direction--very balanced. Good stuff.
Wow... Bubblegum, caramel, and sweet fruit. Great beer with a lot of character and a little alcohol bite.

Bottle, 12 vintage.  Clear brown pour with a fleeting white head.  Bourbon and caramel malt aromas.  Sweet and delicious with loads of caramel malts, dark fruits, velvety smooth bourbon and woody back beats.  A fantastic barrel aged barley wine with a very nice mouthfeel and balance.  Impressive....
Pours dark brown with a khaki head.  Aroma is candied sugar, bourbon, vanilla.  Taste is sweet with a touch of sour.  Medium bodied and somewhat slick.  Not bad.

15 mar 2013, bottle. Light but brown. Nose s balsamic vinaigrette. Tastes of balsamic vinaigrette and bacon. Something is the matter with this beer



---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared by ygtbsm94. Thanks Brad.

2009 vintage

The beer is a hazy orange hue with a small, oily, beige head. The aroma offers plenty of oak, with additional notes of bourbon, butter, caramels, roast. The flavor brings lots of wood, a light tannic quality, caramels. Medium bodied with moderatley low carbonation. Smooth on the palate. Overall, this was pretty good.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-13-2012
Lots of tannic barrel even at 3 years old. Very delicious rum raisins and bourbon. Not as smooth as it could be but thats just me...

Bomber, 2009 Vintage. Poured deep amber with a short, swirly beige head. The aroma was deep and seductive, with a blend of aged molasses, Port wine, spiked caramels, and dulce de leche.. warm bourbon was almost perfectly integrated.. I love when barrel treatments complement base beers, and this nailed it! The flavor held serve.. tangy and lightly acidic bourbon and oak opened on the tip of the tongue.. warm Port, caramel, and vanilla followed.. the bourbon rolled through and kept the drink bright (not allowing it to turn into a sugary malt bomb).. finished with delicious, softly aged malts, bourbon tang, and a hint of coconut. Heavy-bodied with lower carbonation on the palate.. very good balance.. awesome brew!

2009 bottle purchased at Toronado and shared with Bryan. Really a stunning beer. Nose and flavor rife with gorgeous port and madeira vinous tones, mellowed-bourbon vanilla and very little heat after 3.5 years of age, and amazing molasses, caramel, plum, and raisin. Touches of nuttiness and lighter stone fruit shines through as well. Awesome, glad I spotted it on their list.

23rd June 2010Cloudy brown beer. No real head. Minerally nose with sherry and coca cola notes. Softish palate, a tad dry. Sweet coconut and malt. Subtle cherry in the undertone. Moderate and smooth bourbon with a little unsweet wood. Smooth finish with mild bitterness in the aftertaste.

Bomber from City Beer. Pours murky brown with small tan head. Aromas of bourbon, caramel, vanilla, booze, and thick malts. Flavors of thick caramel malts, vanilla, bourbon, and underlying tartness. Little hot and thick but this was pretty tasty..

Pours dark ruby-brown-black with a thin tan head, fast to dissipate. Aroma is dark fruit, vanilla, caramel, bourbon, slightly acidic. Taste is dark fruit, vanilla, caramel, bourbon, and funk. The funkiness here is very nice and a credit to the quality of the beer. The mouthfeel is somewhat syrupy and nice. I liked it. Overall, a very nice barley wine. Very enjoyable. Would certainly get this again.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, vintage 2009. Sweet, complex and very well balanced Barley Wine, slightly oxidized (in a good way). Barrel Ageing did have some effect but 10 months wasnt noticeable.

2011 bottle tasted fresh. It pours very dark ruby brown with a thin ring of tan foam. The aroma is a nice balance of dark red fruit and bourbon. A little bit of acid maybe and strong alcohol esters as well. The flavor is ridiculously rich with lots of raisins, caramel, wood and bourbon. The barrel aging was executed really well here with the bourbon and wood flavors supporting the base beer without overwhelming it. The mouthfeel is very thick and slick with low carbonation. Not exactly flat, but close. Its perhaps a bit hot at the moment. An enjoyable sipper.

2009. Holy crap, Sean, thanks for sharing this ancient Whale! Another beer I never thought Id try. Cool, the aroma lays a little flat, but gives some fruity spice and a touch of that warming oaky Bourbon. Chewy, refined silky sugars hold up a graceful and mature rich malt base. Figs, plums, and candied apples. Based on memory, this tastes as good, if not better, as any other Bourbon barrel Barleywines Ive had. Noticeable warmth brings up the finish and helps me remember the joys of autumn. Little oxidation, has held up well. Married, smooth, with a nice balance of noticeable Bourbon barrel and the good, complex malts. A special treat.

Bottle shared at a recent BA/RB tasting... [2009 Vintage] Poured dark orange with a thin head.  Slightly oxidized. Bourbon whiskey tones with oak, heat, and strong sweetness.  Still some hop bitterness which balanced everything fairly well.  Toasted grains and very much sugar forward.

2009 Bomber shared with friends. Deep brown pour with little head. Huge oak, vanilla, bourbon and citrus all poking through in the aroma. Great flavor blend. Sweet malt, caramel, vanilla, citrus hops and bourbon in the taste. A tad sweet, but very smooth and not boozy. Very nice.

Deep amber brown pour with a thin tan head.  The aroma is rich and chewy.  Sweet and a little bit earthy as well.  Lots of rich Belgian-type malt character.  Fairly rich sweet caramel malt and a bit of fruitiness as well.  Lightly tart with a touch of sweet oak rounding the hops out a bit.  Pretty tasty stuff.
Bottle at Max and Jesss place.  Pours a hazed orange amber.  Light booze, malt and oxidization on the nose.  Super sweet.  Oxidized and toasty.  A touch of alcohol, and sweet vanilla on the finish.

Bottle at Maxs tasting. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Sweet caramel malt aroma with some bourbon sweetness.  The flavor has bourbon, some candy sweetness, and light toasty/roasty note, and sweet malts. Solid.
2009 Vintage flöska. Hazy deep red.brown colour. Dark fruity woodish bit sour pleasant sweet aroma. Good mouthfeel. Flavour is sweet, has dark fruits, wood, some vanilla, bit notice of alc.

Bomber shared by BOLTZ.  Pours cloudy brown with a thin head.  The nose is dark fruits, caramel and bourbon.  The taste is the same with more bourbon than the aroma.  I like bourbon so its all good.  Medium bodied.  Off-balance but tasty. Thanks J!
Bottle shared by Plovmand, thanks. Red/brown body with a small offfwhite head. Aroma is sourish, fruity, raisins and bourbon. Flavor is sour notes, raisins, bourbon, wood, caramel.
Bottle (Vintage 2009) at Plovmands - Thanks. Cloudy red/brown - offwhite head. Bourbon, coconut, sweetness, raisins, ryebread notes, roasted, barley, vanilla, wooden, fruity, dark fruits. Nice.

Pours dark mahogany with a foamy head.  Aroma of sweet malt, bourbon, wood and vanilla.  Flavor is big on bourbon, with caramel, dark fruit, vanilla, oak and some hop bitterness.  A pretty nice BW with loads of bourbon.

Bottled. Vintage 2009. Reddish dark amber coloured. Unclear. small beige head. Vanilla, sweetness, wood, light sourness, ripe fruits. flavour is sweet and fruity. vanilla, wood, Medium to full bodied. Woody and sweet vanilla end. Smooth and balanced.

clear dark amber, smooth offwhite to beige head.
woody, sourish and dusty aroma,
flavor is very nice. barley wine, but with a slighlty fruity and woody twist.

Bottle. Thanks Doodler for the trade!!! Reddish brown with a creamy dense off white head. The aroma is sweet fruity, light acidic, barley, caramel, berries and light hops. The flavour is sweet malty, sweet caramel, ripe fruit, barley, leather, vanilla and light alcohol. Great attempt!
Acorn brown, poly(?) white wisps. Nose of light booze, cardboard, chocolate cake. Flavor is soy, whiskey, light caramel malt. Light burn. Pleasant stuff, enjoyable, but not something Ill hunt for.
Bottled. An unclear brown beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of malt, bourbon, and wood. The flaovr is sweet with notes of malt, alcohol, bourbon, and a bit of wood.

650 ml bottle thanks to footbalm. 2009 vintage. Pours a very murky dark brown color with a large off-white head. The aroma is very sweet bourbon, vanilla some fruity malts. The flavor is dominated by a very nice rich bourbon barrel; huge vanilla, woody, smooth, some light earthy hops. Very good.

Bottle shared by DuffmanSW at Hangar 24 brewery.  Poured a brown color with thick tan head. Aroma was mildly tart with bourbon booze and oak. Taste was sweet raisins, coconut and brown sugar. Nice carbonation. Overall very good stuff.

22oz courtesy of ygtbsm94. Bottle #151/180. Obviously winding down to the final few beers of the DC Local Tasting. The appearance is a muddy brune/mahogany with cask bubbles and not really a "head". Aroma of sherry, oxidized apples, mulled cider, hot bourbon. Taste is sherry, dark fruits, brown sugar, toffee, heavy bourbon, warming alcohol. Some balancing bitterness. In your face and fairly intense.

09 -bottle-thanks wavers1 via jtclockwork for sharing-pours a light brown head and dark red/brown color.  Aroma is plum/date/cherry, dark malt-toffee, slight alcohol, cinnamon stick/vanilla.  Taste is bourbon/wood, plum/date/tart cherry, dark malt-toffee, slight alcohol, cinnamon stick/vanilla.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2013 Bottle acquired via trade with dstructo...thanks Ryan!  Small eggshell foam floated above a raisin colored body.  Aroma is heavy bourbon, wood, vanilla, and cocoa.  Flavor is also dominated by bourbon, tilting towards excessive, with caramel, toffee, dark fruit, and brown sugar filling in the gaps.  Fairly thick and syrupy...wanted to try this for a while!  A little more assertive than I would have liked.

22oz bottle, thanks ygtbsm94.  Small beige head atop clear brown body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, chocolate, some Bourbon, caramel.  Taste is moderately sweet, milk chocolate, some Bourbon, caramel.  Sticky full body.

Bottle courtesy of ygtbsm94, thanks!  I think its really stupid that brewers are forced to add the unnecessary words "style ale" onto the label.  But I digress.  Plenty of whiskey in this one, in the aroma and the taste, bu too much for my taste.

Bottle.  Pours clear tawny with a small, fizzy beige head with no lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (caramel, toffee, nutty, toast), light hops (floral), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of alcohol, dates, wood, and bourbon.  Flavor is heavy malt (caramel, toffee, nutty, toast), light hops (floral), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of alcohol, dates, wood, and bourbon.  Full body, moderate warmth, medium carbonation, light creaminess with a sweet texture and dry finish.

Bottle thanks to ygtbsm94: Pours a transparent deep copper mahogany with a spotty-lacing off-white head.  Has a semi-sweet toasty caramel nose with rich bourbon oak and vanilla complexity.  Starts with good rich caramel sweetness and nice bourbon oak balance before a warming chewy complex finish.  A nice bourbon-barrel aged barleywine.
Big sweet, bourbon nose, lots of buttery coconut, lots of toffee and dark fruit. The taste is sweet, lots of bourbon, but not too boozy, nice coconut and vanilla, some sherry/oxidation. Solid.

22oz bottle, 2009 edition, most generously shared by peteinsd at the PP bottle shop in Carlsbad. thanks so much, peter! pours a hazy, deep mahogany with flecks of gold and a thick, creamy, off-white head with sticky lacing. aroma is great, very unique for a bourbon barrel barley wine, with tart plum skins, wet oak, sour mash bourbon/whiskey, and grassy hops with a touch of sweet caramel and vanilla as it warmed. flavor is wonderful with the dark malts, huge caramel, and toffee coming to the forefront and backed by woody bourbon, raisins, and light brandy notes with hints of tast grapes and berries hiding amidst the sweetness. palate is full bodied, sticky sweet, and had a nice spicy, woody note of the finish. overall, and awesome barely wine. damn sham i may never try this one again.

From notes.  2009 Vintage.  Tasted from bomber bottle on my birthday.  Purchased at The Jug Shop in San Francisco.  Pours clear dark amber with a thick tan head that leaves thick lace.  The nose is American oak with Dill, coconut, and cinnamon all the way through.  There is also some brown sugar malt and chocolate sweetness.  As it warms, some fruity cherry and date aromas also come through.  The flavors are very complex with vanilla and cinnamon, oaky bourbon, cherry, date, brown sugar sweetness, and toasty malts.  The body is medium plus with average carbonation and a long, complex bourbon finish.

Aroma is somewhat tart from the sweet barley wine and bourbon.  The aroma provides no clue as to the mad decadence of the flavor.  Taste is vigorous rich raisin-laden barley wine with rich bourbon.  The melding of the barley wine and bourbon is flawless (nothing out of place).  As the beer warms I get an absolute symphony of barley wine/bourbon and some wonderful bourbon reverberations in the finish.  This beer is insanely good {whimpering noises as I realize Ill likely never see it again}.

22oz bottle (2009) from wavers1, thanks man 
Appearance: Pours dark mahogany with a nice frothy beige head and some lacing 
Aroma: Sweet malts, bourbon, woody and vanilla 
Taste: Smooth and silky mouthfeel. Bourbon, vanilla, oak with some hop bitterness in the finish 
This is a great Barleywine, the best Ive had. The bourbon is very present, but not overpowering. Very refreshing.

Bottle with many thanks to wavers1. Pours plum with tan head. Nose of plum, date, earthy lambic, cherry, cinnamon stick and vanilla. Taste is same with bourbon and oak. Very light alcohol presence. Absolutely top notch.

2009. Simply an amazing beer. Aroma is sour, bready, oak vanilla. Pours a dark reddish brown, thin tan head, yeast floaties. Sweet vanilla, whiskey. The bourbon is there in the background but not overpowering like alot of these beers. Finish has slight astringence. Alcohol is not really detectable. Exquisite balance. Perfection on every level.

Bottle 116 of 180 with a big thanks to ditmier for sharing this. Pours out a cloudy amber topped with a small tan head. Aroma was great lots of sweetness. Caramel, brown sugar, pit fruit, vanilla, bourbon, and oak. Taste was just as good. More of the sweetness caramel, pit fruit, rich malts, and the barrel. A very well done BA Barley Wine.

Low carbonation pour on this 2009 bottle, but the taste is a very nice melding of sweet bourbon elements and slightly citric hop flavors on the back end with moderate bitterness.  A very solid BA Barleywine, extremely glad I got to try this!

Tigers love pepper... they hate cinnamon. .. Pours a dark bark brown .. lacing is quite good .. . smooth for being a 10% bourbon brew, a bomber wouldnt last long for most people .. . light barrel, molasses, and light chocolate vanilla flavours .. . pick this up if you see it, then purchase it from the store, then go home and chill it, then drink it...

On tap at City Beer. Poures dark brown with a thin beige head and a strong treacle and chocolate aroma. There is a robust slightly sour treacle flavor, with some plum, raisin and chocolate and a smooth bourbon finish. This is a great brew that has been properly aged.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2010 Bottle from City Beer Store. Good grapey-winey  aromas.  Brown colour with some brown head.  Above-average, creamy mouthfeel, caramel malts. Bourbon, and some coconut, a bit of peat in finish.Nicely done, great for style,very drinkable.

Thanks to jhenry04 for this treat!!! - Bottled 2/4/2009 - Heaven Hill #116/180...Pours a hazy amber with only a small ring of beige as a head...aroma is gorgeous, caramel, soft vanilla oak and bourbon, brown sugar and caramel, tons of dk fruit...flavour does not disappoint, sweet and sticky fruity malt right up front, mellow bourbon, caramel, oak...still displayed prickly carbonation despite the appearance that suggested otherwise, and it cuts through the gravity nicely...never really expected to see a bottle of this, and it was fantastic!

RBSG09 Grand Tasting notes (thanks to whoever brought it). Heaven Hill version. This beer was a treat, even for someone who isnt the biggest proponent of bourbon barrel aging barleywines. A very nice melded, which is not to say weak, Bourbon flavor. The thick, rich malt flavor is sweet and fruity. Some hops were still evident in a peachy capacity, or maybe that was just malt complexity that I was confusing. There were also very nice notes of brown sugar and vanilla.

A: This is not a particularly attractive beer with a hazy mahogany color with very light carbonation and a small tan head.

S: The nose offers plenty of nice sweet caramel with the oak and bourbon providing a nice vanilla aroma. There are some nondescript dark fruits as well.

T: Like the aromas, this one is full of caramel and vanilla deliciousness. Theres a nice toffee and molasses flavor as well, along with the nice bourbon and oak and raisins.

M: The beer is a bit warm, but the low carbonation and fairly full body provide for a pleasant experience.

D: I wasnt the hugest fan of the regular Dipsea, but I found that the barrel aging added quite a bit to it. Im glad Ive been able to try this one a couple times now.

Thanks to xmarcnolanx for sharing this one.  Pours dark brown with a small tan head.  The aroma has cardboard, bourbon, caramel malt with the barleywine strength and some apples.  Medium / full body that is smooth and has light carbonation.  The flavor starts with alcohol and barleywine thick caramel malt along with quite a bit of sugariness.  the finish has quite a bit of green apple, bourbon and oak.

Bomber, Heaven Hill version bottle #

Pours a deep mahogany that shows brighter amber when held up to light and a small bubbly off-white head that recedes quickly to a small collar.

The aroma is sweet with caramel malts and vanilla and the dryness from the barrels coming through as well.  There is a watery bourbon aroma that leaves a slight burn in the nostrils with each whiff.  Underwhelming aroma to be honest.

The taste steps it up a bit.  There is the caramel malt backbone but there are some dark fruits that compliment the bourbon better than the more watered down aromas Im getting.  Its like rum-soaked raisins.  The finish is sweet with brown sugar, vanilla and bourbon.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied and very slick - bordering on watery, even for a bourbon-barrel beer.

This is a very good barleywine, with the taste really standing out to me.  The body is a little light for me and keeps it from being a world-class beer.  Its extremely drinkable and one of the easiest-drinking BBBWs Ive had.

Aroma is sweet bourbon, vanilla, dull hops, and caramel.
Pours very lightly carbonated.
Taste is bourbon, vanilla, a slight sourness, peat.  
Finish is a bit sour and watery.  Oak is present, but not overwhelming- in no way aggressive.  Bourbon is also well done, but I feel like the overall beer is a bit thin and uninteresting.  The bourbon and oak impart the complexity to this beer.  
Otherwise, this is a bit underwhelming.

Gad! What a day of treats! Starting with the Hair of the Dog dock sale at 0555hrs., then one heck of a tasting in the evening!  Yet another zymurgistic delight  courtesy of, "hannont"!! Colour... dark brown with no head at all. Nose... very sweet with brown sugar out the wahzoo! Palate... dark brown sugar, molasses, toffee galore, dark corn sirup, and a lovely long coat for my soft palate and throat to wear this winter!

2008 vintage on-tap at Bistros Barrel Aged Festival 09.   Honey brown color with a light haze and small head.   The aroma is just bursting with rich caramel, vanilla, bourbon, brown sugar and dried fruit.   The flavor is similar and very smooth; warming but not really hot.   Full bodied with low carbonation.   The oak is subtle but the overall impression is decidedly very influenced by the beers time in the barrel.   Very nicely done.

22oz bottle from Joey. Orange label with no bottle number... Pours a mostly opaque muddled caramel brown with a quickly dissipating light beige head... Aroma of semi-assertive bourbon and wood with added notes of caramel/toffee... Flavors are of a similar tone. Sweet overall with a light spicy bitterness in the finish. Mouthfeel and body has somewhat thinned out. Still pretty solid overall albeit somewhat boozy.
On tap at Taps grand opening. This 06 aged brew was one of the best, perhaps the best, Ive had. Excellent, excellent palate to go with a smooth malt base and solid hops. Amazing.

22 oz bottle.  I think this was the Heaven Hill version.  Foggy brown with a ring and a dot of foam.  Nose is caramel, cardamon, orange peel, ginger and whiskey; beautifully integrated.  Soft and milky with a slight tang and alcohol warming.  Taste is bourbon, raisin, caramel and a touch of brown sugar.  Smooth, dry finish with vanilla, wood and grass.

Thanks Mike for sharing!  Bottle pours dark amber color with off white head.  Aroma is booze, caramel, and oak.  Viscous mouthfeel.  Flavor is ash,wood, bourbon, the caramel was like it was made by a candy maker, and finished with the bourbon flavor.  I liked the finish the best.  I got a sense of the bourbon and what it tasted like as it melded with the other flavors.  Just brilliant!

650ml bottle

Thanks to Mike I think for cracking this open though it could have been someone else.  This is my first experience with Marin and hopefully not my last.  While bourbon barrel aging big beers is not novel when done right the results are fantastic.  This is no exception though I might place it just short of world class.

Aroma / Appearance - Ruby red with little carbonation the body is a rich blend of bourbon, vanilla, and oak.  I picked up a bit of something a bit off that came through despite the heat of the alcohol and barrel.

Flavor / Palate - Tasting like warm caramel icing followed by a rinse of bourbon this is big and complex.  The hops have taken a back seat to other aspects including in the warm but smooth finish.  A decent example of how to properly age a barleywine I think this one has potential to make a name for itself.

Bottle This beer rocks! Pours a murky caramel-color with a small, creamy, white head. Hurricane-like, swirling retention. The nose is an intoxicating swirl of oak, whiskey, caramel, vanilla and coconut. Full-bodied with tingly carbonation. The tangy, sweet flavor offers caramel, bourbon and a rumor of oak. There is a lot of bourbon flavor without a lot of bourbon heat. The lengthy finish is sweet and tangy and bequeaths lingering, rich notes of brown sugar and whiskey. Big time thanks to daknole for sharing his bottle of this world class beer!

Bottle 65 cl. Pours a cloudy opaque dark brown with a creamy, beige head. Aroma has lots overripe fruit, bourbon and licorice allsorts. Quite full-bodied, again lots of caramel and overripe fruit. Sweet caramel and a warming alcohol in the finish. Absolutely no bitterness. 110709
(A couple 22oz bottles)  Pours a hazy mahogany body with a small beige head.  Aroma of vanilla, bourbon, caramel, and toffee.  Flavor of caramel malt, hops (herbal), dark fruit, vanilla, and bourbon.

Bottle #16 from iowaherkeye.  Damn what a beauty. Pours a nice cloudy brown with a small tan head.  Aroma is pure sweet bourbon, caramel and oak.  Flavor is so well rounded.  Smooth and sweet with such wonderful bourbon notes.  Vanilla flavors, brown sugar, oak, and more.  Damn this was amazing.  I wish I had more of this!!

22oz bottle, Heaven Hill Barrel. Huge thanks to Daknole for busting out this super rare beer. Pours hazy brown with a small beige head. Nose is intense caramel and brown sugar. A little cinnamon and a whiff of bourbon and smoke. Fantastic nose. Flavor is intense fruity caramel. Layers of vanilla and chocolate, a little bit of brown sugar and molasses. Bourbon on the back end. No real alcohol bite even as it warms. This is super balanced with perfect carbonation. Probably the best American Barley Wine Ive had. Simply outstanding.

22 fl oz bottle. Pours hazy dark orange to brown with a small off-white head. Smooth and fruity barrel aged aroma. Light eye burn. Vanilla and chocolate malt flavoured. Mild wooden and vanilla finish. Very smooth.

Name: Old Dipsea Barleywine Style Ale, BA
Date: July 11, 2009
Mode: Bottle
Source: RBSG 2009
Appearance: hazy dark amber, scant head
Aroma: sweet dark caramel and vanilla aroma
Flavor: rich caramel malt flavor, nice bourbon, sweet vanilla, balancing oakyness, touch of alcohol
Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20
Rating: 3.6/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **4

RBSG09 bottle on the bus after the grand tasting.  cquiroga said this was the Heaven Hill barrel version, one of only 190 bottles.  Pours dark brown with some ruby highlights and a tan head.  Aroma is big on caramel and molasses with dark fruity notes and a very smooth vanilla bourbon note.  Flavor is also very smooth with toffee, vanilla, light booze, almonds, black cherry, and brown sugar.  Totally silky on the palate.  I loved it.

Shared by jhenry04, I think, at RBSG09 Grand Tasting.  Has a thick dark brown color. Aroma is molasses, alcoholic raisin, and well more alcohol from the barrel I guess.  All the alcohol becomes a bit astringent but the big sweet things underneath it are cool.  The flavor is bit different where the alcohol becomes that astringent cherry but the underneath big sweet malts come off as brown sugar.  In the end its a BA barley wine, so it is what it is...........
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: UPDATED: DEC 20, 2009 Bottle shared at GT 09.  Aroma is bourbon with heat, sweet wood, molasses, caramel and hop syrup.  Flavor is very much the same, with alcohol sharpening everything.  Well balanced indeed, but a touch hot at the moment - not that it should stop anyone from drinking it.
Light brown, no head.  Aroma is vanilla, oak, bourbon, toffee, malt and alcohol.  Taste is earthy, oaky, toffee, alcohol, nice hop/malt balance.

Huge thanks to pepsican, badbeer, and iowaherkeye. 20 year old fitzgerald barrels 110/180. Seemed simple at first but kept evolving. Nice hardwood character. Really alcoholic aroma, but not bad. Nice caramel, slightly chocolaty finish. Vanilla & hazelnut. Very complex.

20 year fitzi barrel, 110/180. Murky brown with a small tan head.  Oak, raisin, plum, and tobacco.  Flavor was loaded with caramel and toffee,  some cherry, oak, chocolate, and a bit of plastic. Finished boozy,  nice long rich finish.  Decent carbonation.  Thanks joey!

22 oz. bottle - 2009 Heaven Hill version, bottle #139/180; thanks riversideak for this rare treat; drank side by side with the Pelican Perfect Storm; pours muddy, dark brown with musky aromas of sweet bourbon, oak, brown sugar and a touch of ethanol; yummy going down with toffee, tobacco, vanilla; texture is thinned out from the wood and bourbon is more mild than the Perfect Storm; dry finish and drinks stronger than 9%; quite subtle overall and while rich, it is not too sweet; i dont care much for the base beer, so this was a big improvement though not quite up to the Perfect Storm level for me

8 month Heaven Hill edition.  Poured a brownish red color with an off-white head.  The bourbon barrel dominates but not over powering.  Vanilla and bourbon nose.  Sweet malt flavor.  Fruity taste with some bourbon mixed in.  Nice warming sensation but no alcohol taste.  medium-full bodied.

From a 22oz Bottle, 2009 Vintage.  Heaven Hill Bourbon Barrel, #33/180.  Generously shared by rallison.  Mostly transparent, ruddy mahagony colored body with a thin layer of tight bubbled beige head.  Intense bourbon aromas dripping of vanilla and pretzel dough barrel qualities.  Moderately alcoholic, with notes of fig, fruitcake, brown sugar, and a light peppery spice, although more cardamom-like than black pepper.  No hop aroma.  Full bodied, soft-moderately carbonated mouthfeel with a rich, silky texure.  Sweet flavors of maple syrup and pecan brittle explode over the palate, softened by some of the oaky vanilla.  Suggestions of english toffee and butterscotch, although not at all in a d-kind of way.  Light fruity characters also emerge, although they have more of a fruitcake, spiced bready quality.  Finishes sweet, but not cloyingly so, with the silky barrel flavors slowly fading on the tongue.  Easily one of the best bourbon barrel beers Ive had in a really long time.  Thanks for sharing, Ryan!

Bomber from Joey (iowaherkeye) with an orange sticker so it was the Heavens Hill barrel. Thanks a ton Joey! Awesome light bourbon nose, with some toffee, dark fruit, and more light bourbon. Clear dark brown with a very small beige head receding into a ring of bubbles. Flavor is very oaky vanilla, light bourbon, and dark fruitiness. Finish is very oaky vanilla woodiness and only a hint of alcohol.

(2009 bottle by way of irishboy)brown body with no head.the aroma is a lovely blend of vanilla,bourbon,candy sugar,and brown sugar.the flavor does much of the same.honestly im just blown away at how well the barrel aging did for this beer.its perfectly balanced,alcohol is well hidden,and the palate is out of this world.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brune body with an off white head.  Chocolate, bourbon, light woodiness and some dark fruit.  Very smooth with a light chocolate silk character and vanilla oak accents.  Great beer.
Shared by YGTBSM94.  Not sure which vintage.  Very nice beer.  Very well attenuated.  Great flavor.  Sweet but not cloying.  Mild bourbon and wood flavor.
Pours clear dark brown with a tan ring of foam. Sweet aroma of chocolate and fruit. Nice liquid fruitcake taste. This would be very interesting in a few years.

Sample from a bottle shared by riversideAK (???)  Heaven Hill version. Tawny brown colored body, small tan ring of a head.  Clear and surprisingly light colored, not that it matters.  Nose is strangely minty and solvent-like, the bourbon character seems spicy/peppery/gin-like, with your more typical vanilla, almond and wood character not playing a primary role.  Body is disappointingly weak and sharp - not something I like at all - while the sweet caramel malts and vanilla/bourbon focused flavors seem detached, stale and overall just very mild.  Surprised that this one came across so... bland?

Bottle #35/180. Date of 2/4/09. Dark mahogony/brown beer with a thin tan head. Sweet malt aroma with caramel and bourbon. Bourbon flavor with caramel and brown sugar. Medium bodied. Carbonation a little light. Bourbon , vanilla, and oak lingers with caramel and malt.

Tasted during the Nor Cal Beer Geek Tasting on 3/11/2009. This barleywine pours a cloudy deep amber brown color from a 22oz bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is bourbon, oak, vanilla and caramel malts. A full-bodied barleywine. The malts are caramel, fruity and sweet. The hops are earthy. Full flavored barrel aged beer, lots of oak, vanilla an bourbon flavors. Very smooth taste. Very small amount of carbonation is this one, but it doesnt seem to affect the taste much. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is sweet and bourbonish.

Side by side rating of the Heaven Hill version and the 12 year old fitzgerald.  Both are great.  And at this point in the tasting i could only notice subtle differences.  Heaven hill pours clearer brown than the old fitz.  Both noses are pretty sweet and rich with lots of bourbon.  Taste for both are pretty amazing, chewy, rich very rich very balanced and overall beyond excellent.

Bottle from brewery. Dark brown with no head. Caramel vanilla bourbon toasted coconut and oak aroma. Buttery palate. Vanilla caramel bourbon and oak and toasted coconut taste with a nice alcohol warmth. Excellent.

Bottle 32/180 2009 Heaven Hill Barrels) Slight head formed. More so when I pour straight down the mouth of the glass, but it falls quickly. Little carbonation visibly present. Dark orange cloudy body. Aromas of vanilla and oak.. Smooth very pronounced vanilla flavors, with bourbon alcohol finish on the tongue. I think aging this a bit more would would really help to mellow out the pronounced flavor, but Id be concerned about aging it too much more for fear of losing what carbonation is still in there. Will put the release date on the calendar next year to lay in a good supply!

22oz. bottle, green sticker on cap, neck label says Bourbon Barrel Aged in a 20-year Old Fitzgerald barrel for 7 months, Unfiltered, Bottled 1/5/09, #133/180, with a huge thanks to AgentSteve for this!  Pours a nearly clear dark amber with ruby highlights and a small foamy tan head.  Aroma is absolutely lovely, with bourbon, oak, vanilla, caramel, brown sugar, and dark fruits in near perfect harmony.  Flavor also shines, with these same components working very well together.  A bit prickly start on the palate, followed by a smooth finish.  Wow, Ive been on a BA barleywine kick lately to finish up the winter season, and like FS Wooden Hell, this one did not disappoint; thanks again Steve!

To clarify with the commercial description--there are two different bottlings of the 2009 release: the ones with the labels on the neck are as described (on the neck): from 20 year Old Fitzgerald barrels, Those also have a green sticker on the cap.  There are also 180 bottles that were in 12 year Heaven Hill barrels, though they are unlabeled on the neck and have an orange sticker on the cap.  This first rating will be the orange stickered, Heaven Hill barrel.  Clear medium brown with a 1/2 finger beige head after a vigorous pout, and didnt last long before fading to a thick ring and thin film.  Toasted oak and vanilla is dominant, though not harsh in the aroma--with a good amount of brown sugar and raisins behind.  Oh man, the flavor gets even better--the word pleasing keeps coming to mind.  Lots of sweet brown sugar and raisins, maybe a bit of prunes.  This gets nowhere near cloying thanks to the barrel--plenty of toasted oak and vanilla (again), and some light spicy alcohol in the mouth, that does warm the throat going down.  Theres also a little milk chocolate and coconut in the semi-dry finish.  Low bitterness.  Full smooth body with low carbonation--I thought Id want more carbonation, but I dont here.  Shit, this is good--I cant think of a better BA (bourbon) beer in recent memory.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text:
Sampled at Toronado 2009 Barleywine Festival.
Pours slightly hazy amber with copper edges and thin white head. The aroma is smooth bourbon booze and bright wood notes followed by molasses, vanilla and alcohol heat. The taste begins with bourbon and near bright wood followed by sweet ripe cherries, prunes and sugar stewed raisins. By midway and into the finish pleasing layers of molasses murmur to the surface.

Draught at the brewpub
Murky, dark brown with a tan head.
Loads of sweet fruits and oak in the aroma.
Sweet, almost sugary flavour. Dark chocolate and a lot of vanilla and wood.

On tap at Toronado for Barleywine fest 09.  Amber color with an off-white head.  Aroma of caramel malt, bourbon, vanilla, and wood.  Flavor is sweet and malty with brown sugar, bourbon, port, and vanilla.  Smooth mouthfeel.
Toronado Barleywine Fest.  Pours amber brown, caramel, dark fruits, brown sugar, wood, vanilla, little bourbon.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2010 Draft @ Bistro BA Fest.  Pours a viscous, slightly murky, orange and brown-sugar color; oily and headless.  Lots of dense, chewy bourbon, brown sugar, and viscous barrel notes; reasonably well-hidden alcohol.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: chewy brown sugar, caramel, and dried fruits; solid viscosity, with the oak coming through as toastiness and a light butterscotch presence; nicely creamy and soft overall; toasty wood.  Lengthy finish: dried fruits, wood-infused sugars, and some light vanilla; soft presence throughout. 8.4.7.4.15=3.8

Rerate, 22oz bottle, #6 of 180, courtesy of Mario. Thanks, dude! This was the Heaven Hill barrel version, whether or not that warrants a separate listing. Pours a dark, caramel color; slight viscosity; thin, medium tan head with patchy lacing. Pleasantly rounded nose of whiskey barrel notes, mild sour mash, and oily, dark fruits; a very pleasant, rounded bourbon character; definitely a sour-mash note. Medium-full body; relaxed CO2; lightly creamy and non-astringent, with a medium presence of warming alcohol; light presence of higher alcohols; dense, sweet dark fruits, warming bourbon (vanilla, fruity, lightly charred wood), and a light charred, toasty note; very pleasant warming bourbon, reasonably well-attenuated, but a touch rough at the edges; tasty, but a bit messy. Lasting finish of toasty oak, warming sweet bourbon, and dark fruits; on the sweet side.

On tap @ Bistro BA Fest poured a clear copper with no head. Aromas of bourbon, carmel, oak and vanilla. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of bourbon, oak, carmel and vanilla with a smooth lingering bourbon finish.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2009 Poured a beautiful deep brown with a halo around my glass. The nose was huge with dried fruits, brown sugar, oak, coconut, vanilla and alcohol. The flavor was quite the same, and the heat made the finish a bit long. Tastes way stronger than 9%.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2009 Bottle generously opened by Tim at the PP bottle shop.  Tasted with Tim, Ryan and Sean.  Huge, huge thanks Tim for letting me try this tasty treat.  Looks like Im the first rating for this (hopefully not the last, since there are only 180 bottles).  They need to brew a ton more of this.  A rival to Angels Share.  Bottle #72/180.  Bottled in 3/2/2007, tasted 4/29/08, so there a nice amount of bottle aging as well.  Tasted side-by-side against the un barrel aged.  Clearly this is much better.  The un-barrel aged I give the same rating of 3.9, that I rated when I tried it early.  The barrel aged beast I give a 4.9.  It is wonderful what a little barrel and bottle aging will do to a barleywine.  Pours a thick dark amber color with more head than the un barrel aged.  Why is that?  Lots of buttery caramelized oak aromas.  Sweet, soft, mellow texture.  Bourbon barrel aged, but NO over the top bourbon burn, thank you, which reduces drinkability.  The perfect aroma gets even better as the beer warms up.  Very easy to drink, as I sample, and sample, and sample again.  Yum.  Would love to do a side-by-side with the Angels Shares and BA Old Numbskull.  I think this would win in a blind test, even though it might score the same as Angels Share.
   Tried the other 2 version at the seaofloydster tasting:  heavenhill:  wow, sweet, mellow easy to drink.  4, 9.5,9.5,4.5,18:  4.7.  fitzgerald:  sweet and delicious, a bit hotter.  Malty.  Excellent:  4,9,4,8,18:4.3
